ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a broad overview of the intricate history of agriculture and imperialism, delving into specific examples and engaging with really fascinating literature. Definitely gained some reading comprehension skills here given how dense and informative the readings tended to be.
imperialism and how its shaped environments, peoples, and economies around the world
I learned how to do interviews for my final project, and a lot about history of empire especially in Hawaii
Through this course I learned how to better read and understand long and challenging humanities readings.
thinking about imperialism, colonialism, the intersections between seemingly innocuous parts of our lives, i.e. fruits, and larger, global systems of oppression and power

I learned about the connection between imperialism, colonialism, capitalism, and an empire of plants. My favorite topics that we discussed were Indigenous ways of knowing and being, migrant labor, and worker resistance.
Topics related to imperialism, capitalism, colonialism, and biocolonialism

I felt like most of this class was independent study so most of what I learned came from my own personal research for my final project. I felt like class time was often spent repeating the same concepts or in discussion with other students about what they were learning in their own independent research or in other classes.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Though my engagement with the course was high, a good portion of the classroom's engagement was relatively low -- this is nothing against them, but definitely speaks to how to better facilitate discussion in a seminar setting. Seminars are meant to be vibrant discussions, and it is tough when the same few people speak up because nobody else is. 

Strengths included the breadth of information and the hugely diverse array of global and historical perspectives we get to engage with from new lenses.

strength: readings are interesting for the most part, prof okihiro is lovely and cultivates a pretty warm seminar vibe
weakness: readings are long and can be pretty dense and academic (non-humanities perspective)

Strengths - lots of great reading and carefully curated content
Weaknesses - a lot of people didn't attend class regularly or engage in discussion which made it hard to feel like discussions were productive
The way the syllabus is structured is amazing. Every week had a slew of interesting readings that allowed me to stay engaged in the course.
strength  Professor, readings

Strengths: most readings/material was very interesting, Professor Okihiro is very knowledgeable and supportive
Weaknesses: readings were very dense/difficult to understand sometimes, class discussion felt unstructured at times
The readings are very interesting, but a lot to get through in a week. Prof. Okihiros short lectures at the beginning of class were great. Sometimes the discussion felt a little directionless.

Strengths are that the Prof is very kind and considerate in terms of communication and that if you are really interested in the topics of this course you have an opportunity to delve deep into your own research for the entire semester. Weaknesses were that class time was not spent learning much material but discussing independent work or outside material with other students. Lectures were often very cyclical and returned to similar topics weekly with different readings.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would, but beware the weekly reading load. If you really want to get anything out of this class, you will need to engage with the readings and the discussions. There are plenty who sit back and choose not to do the readings or speak in class, and there is no shame in that, but if you really want to take as much out of the course as possible (which you should want to!! it is so interesting!!) it takes a lot of work.

yes definitely! as a non-humanities person, this class was pretty difficult, but i learned a lot and it made me question stuff about the world i hadn't before. the seminar can be a bit one-sided in its leftism (not sure exactly how to word this), but i don't think it hurt the discussions.
Yes - I learned a lot and Prof Okihiro is wonderful!
yes!
Yes, I would recommend this course to any student interested in studying colonialism, imperialism, and about indigenous peoples.
Id recommend it. Professor Okihiro is a master in the field and you learn a lot from him
Yes, especially if you are interested in learning more about imperialism, land, labor, and fruits.
Yes, but make sure you are motivated to do the readings and engage with the class or you might not learn as much as you hope.
Only if they know they are particularly interested in the topics of this course and have an idea or tentative ideas about independent work that they would like to do related to these topics.
